data.title: Canada’s monthly GDP rises 0.1% in September
data.description: • Monthly GDP MoM in Canada increased to 0.1% in September from -0.30% in August of 2025.

data.title: Western Digital is benefiting from 'robust' cloud momentum, analysts say
data.description:
Western Digital's (WDC) quarterly results and guidance are strong indications that the artificial intelligence spending surge is not slowing down anytime soon, Wall Street firms said.

Shares rose nearly 10% in premarket trading, while competitors Seagate Technology (STX) and SanDisk (SNDK) also moved higher.

“Echoing comments similar to its peer [Seagate], WDC noted continued demand from hyperscalers/cloud customers with significant data generation amidst ramping AI adoption,” Citi analyst Asiya Merchant wrote in a note to clients. “To meet demand, customers are adopting higher-capacity drives at a faster pace and WDC is accelerating planned technology transitions for their next gen ePMR and HAMR qualifications. Notably, the company now has 7 customers with firm orders through 1HCY26 with 5 of them covering all of CY26, plus their largest hyperscaler customer agreement through all of CY27.”

Merchant maintained her Buy rating on Western Digital, upped her price target to $180 from $135 and opened an Upside 90-Day catalyst watch on Western Digital.

Cantor Fitzgerald analyst C.J. Muse reiterated that Western Digital is a Top Pick for the firm, given the strength in the hard-disk drive market.

“And considering we are only in the early innings of the AI Infrastructure build, coupled with the HDD oligopoly acting as an oligopoly (only adding capacity through EB transitions, manufacturing/ test efficiencies and automation, confirmed adding zero unit capacity), we expect tightness to only continue if not worsen in the quarters ahead,” Muse wrote in a note to clients.

Muse has an Overweight rating on Western Digital and upped his price target to $200 from $160.

data.title: Getty stock surges as company strikes partnership with AI search engine firm Perplexity
data.description:
Getty Images (GETY) stock was surging as the visual content creator and marketplace announced an agreement with the San Francisco-based AI search engine firm Perplexity.

GETY shares were +54.23% to $3.10 Friday pre-market.

The global multi-year licensing agreement covers the display of Getty's images across Perplexity's search and discovery tools.

"This agreement paves the way for a productive and collaborative partnership between our companies, where we will work together to improve attribution of our contributors' work and Getty Images’ high-quality creative and editorial content will enhance Perplexity's platform," said Nick Unsworth, vice president strategic development at Getty.

"Together, we're helping people discover answers through powerful visual storytelling while ensuring they always know where that content comes from and who created it," said Jessica Chan, head of content and publisher partnerships at Perplexity.

data.title: Carlyle Group stock slides after Q3 earnings reflects disappointing fees
data.description:
Carlyle Group (CG) stock sank 4.2% in Friday premarket trading after the alternative asset manager's Q3 earnings and revenue came in markedly short of Wall Street expectations as realized performance revenue slumped and fund management fees disappointed in the quarter.

Q3 distributable EPS of $0.96, trailing the average analyst estimate of $1.02, rose from $0.91 in Q2 and $0.95 in last year's Q3.

Q3 total segment revenue of $782.5M, missing the $979.9M consensus, decreased from $984.0M in the prior quarter and $895.0M in the year-ago period. Realized performance revenue dropped to $61.7M from $259.8M in Q2 and $275.9M in Q3 2024 and missed the Visible Alpha consensus of $92.6M.

Fee-related earnings of $311.9M, lagging the $314.8M Visible Alpha estimate, fell from $323.3M in Q2 and increased from $277.9M in Q3 2024.

Total assets under management of $474B at Sept. 30, 2025, climbed 2% Q/Q and 6% Y/Y. The sequential improvement was driven by a 6% increase in Carlyle AlpInvest AUM and a 3% increase Global Credit AUM.

Carlyle (CG) had $16.9B of inflows in the quarter, driven by its insurance solutions business, U.S. and Europe structured credit, and asset-backed finance strategies in Global Credit. That compared with $13.4B inflows in Q2.

Fund management fees of $573.9.6M, vs. the Visible Alpha estimate of $577.7M, fell from $589.6M in the previous quarter and rose from $526.5M a year ago.

Q3 total segment expenses of $414.1M dropped from $553.0M in Q2 and $527.9M in last year's Q3.

Carlyle Group (CG) deployed $11.8B and realized $6.1B in proceeds during the quarter.

Conference call at 8:30 AM ET.

Earlier, Carlyle Non-GAAP EPS of $0.96 misses by $0.06

data.title: Exxon slips as Q3 earnings top estimates but fall Y/Y; Permian, Guyana set production records
data.description:
Exxon Mobil (XOM) -1.6% pre-market Friday despite beating Q3 adjusted earnings estimates, helped by higher oil and gas production in Guyana and the Permian Basin, and raising its quarterly dividend by 4% to $1.03/share from $0.99.

Q3 net profit fell to $7.55 billion, or $1.76/share, from $8.61 billion, or $1.92/share, in the year-earlier quarter, and revenues fell 5.2% Y/Y to $85.29 billion, attributed to weaker crude prices, bottom-of-cycle chemical margins, higher depreciation, growth costs, and lower base volumes from strategic divestments, partially offset by volume growth in Guyana and the Permian Basin, and additional structural cost savings; Q3 adjusted profit totaled $8.1 billion, or $1.88/share, exceeding Wall Street expectations.

Q3 cash flow from operating activities totaled $14.8 billion and free cash flow was $6.3 billion.

Exxon (XOM) said it expects this year's capital spending, excluding acquisitions, to come in slightly below the low end of its $27 billion-$29 billion guidance range.

Q3 results benefited from the start-up of the 250,000 bbl/day Yellowtail development in Guyana, where the company broke a quarterly production record surpassing 700,000 bbl/day; in the Permian Basin, production also set a record of nearly 1.7 million bbl/day.

Total Q3 oil and gas production increased by 139,000 boe/day to 4.8 million boe/day.

Q3 earnings by segment: Upstream earnings rose to $5.68 billion from $5.4 billion in Q2, as higher volumes, driven by record production in Guyana and the Permian, structural cost savings, and stronger crude realizations were partially offset by lower base volumes; Energy Products rose to $1.84 billion from $1.36 billion in Q2, driven by stronger industry refining margins due to supply disruptions, higher volumes from record refinery throughput and advantaged projects growth; Chemical Products rose to $515 million from $293 million in Q2, helped by higher margins, record high-value product sales, and lower expenses; and Specialty Products fell to $740 million from $780 million in Q2, attributed to weaker margins and lower seasonal volumes.

"We delivered the highest earnings per share we've had compared to other quarters in a similar oil-price environment," CEO Darren Woods said, noting the company has started up eight of its 10 key 2025 projects, with the remaining two on track. "No one else in our industry is executing at this scale, with this level of innovation, or delivering this kind of value."

Benchmark Brent crude prices averaged $68.17/bbl in Q3, down 13% Y/Y and up 2% Q/Q.

data.title: Flux Power prices $9.6 million public offering
data.description:
• Flux Power Holdings (FLUX) said on Friday it has priced an underwritten public offering of 3.84 million shares of its common stock at $2.50 per share, for expected gross proceeds of about $9.6 million.

  • The company granted the underwriter a 30-day option to purchase up to an additional 576,000 shares to cover over-allotments.
  • Flux Power said the offering is expected to close on November 3, subject to customary conditions. 
  • FLUX -23.49% premarket to $2.8.
  • Source: Press Release
